items.title: GPS trackers reveal 'likely' illegal e-waste exports from Australia to Asia
items.description: A not-for-profit environmental group put GPS devices in 35 e-waste items and dropped them off at recycling locations in four Australian capital cities. Here's what they found.

items.title: Two aspirants who are unlikely to suit the times vie for the Liberal leadership
items.description: Hastie and Taylor each wants to run against Ley. But the two right-wingers can't afford to split the conservative vote on which their tilts would rely.

items.title: A rate hike on Tuesday will be a 'bitter pill' for middle Australia
items.description: Consumer advocates fear a rate hike when the RBA board meets next week could be the "straw that breaks the camel's back" for borrowers in mortgage stress.

items.title: As Trump contemplates action, Iranians send the US a message
items.description: Protesters in Iran are begging US President Donald Trump to launch military action to help topple the Islamic regime. But could it happen?

items.title: 'We can do better': Trump's tsar promises 'safer' Minnesota operation
items.description: Tom Homan says he is working on a plan to pull federal agents out of Minnesota as part of a major strategy shift — but it might not be enough to prevent another US government shutdown

items.title: Singapore without an opposition leader after PM deposes him
items.description: Even for a de facto one-party state, the ruling People's Action Party's decision to dictate who runs Singapore's opposition is remarkable.

items.title: 'Never happened to me': Sabalenka uses anger to book Aus Open final
items.description: World number one Aryna Sabalenka books her fourth consecutive Australian Open final, defeating Ukraine's Elina Svitolina in straight sets.

items.title: Extreme heatwave warning as NSW hits 40+ degrees for sixth day
items.description: As parts of western and south-western New South Wales enter their sixth day of temperatures above 40 degrees, authorities are urging people not to become complacent.

items.title: Celine Cremer went missing in Tasmania. What could have happened to her?
items.description: Celine Cremer went missing in 2023 from a track in a remote part of Tasmania's north-west. With several recent discoveries in the area, these are the theories of what could have happened.

items.title: EU labels Iran's Revolutionary Guards a terrorist organisation in policy shift
items.description: European Union foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas said "repression cannot go unanswered" as the bloc looked set to categorise the IRGC alongside Islamic State and al Qaeda.

items.title: Volunteers concerned over refusal to release taxpayer-funded SES review
items.description: The ABC understands that some female volunteers aired allegations of sexism and discrimination as part of the review, which was undertaken in early 2024.

items.title: 'Mayhem' as fast-moving bushfire engulfs backyards in suburban Perth
items.description: Between six and eight homes were damaged by a fast-moving bushfire in suburban Perth, the Department of Fire and Emergency Services says, with residents who fled the area told to stay away until it is safe to return.

items.title: Melbourne beauty salon firebombed for second time in two days
items.description: About 100 residents have been forced to evacuate their Essendon North apartments in the early hours for a second night in a row.

items.title: Fatal dog attack on beloved mare highlights feral animal control struggle
items.description: The challenges of wild dog management again surface after a pack of feral canines fatally attack a much-loved elderly mare.

items.title: Adelaide's median house price inches closer to $1 million
items.description: Experts are forecasting continued growth this year as Adelaide's metropolitan median house sale price inches closer to $1 million, according to Valuer-General data.

items.title: Trump says Putin agreed not to target Kyiv for one week during cold
items.description: Ukrainians, including residents of the country's capital, are experiencing their toughest winter of the war as Russian attacks target electricity infrastructure.

items.title: Weekly news quiz: BAFTA nominations, a new cricket captain and departing pandas
items.description: Think you've been paying attention to the news cycle?

items.title: Hastie and Taylor fail to agree on plan to oust Ley despite clandestine meeting
items.description: The two conservative men vying to replace Sussan Ley as leader of the Liberal Party met in Melbourne before attending a memorial service for their former colleague Katie Allen.

items.title: Howard's cheat sheet could prove handy for the Coalition
items.description: Former prime minister John Howard once observed that Pauline Hanson was an "electoral gift to the Labor Party". His words proved relevant this week as the Coalition's chaos dragged on.

items.title: CCTV shows triple murder suspect at police station on day of shooting
items.description: The NSW Police commissioner says a surge in domestic violence attacks is a disgrace as police release footage of Julian Ingram, the main suspect wanted over the deadly Lake Cargelligo shooting.

items.title: Shots fired, traffic chaos as allegedly stolen car crashes into school bus
items.description: Two arrests have been made after police shot at an allegedly stolen car that collided with a school bus before driving towards officers in Geelong.

items.title: Why it took nearly 30 minutes for police to evacuate Perth Invasion Day rally
items.description: As police face criticism for their handling of Perth's Invasion Day rally bomb scare, a law enforcement expert says they faced a "no-win situation".

items.title: 'Never seen magnitude' of foreign vessels in Far North Queensland, locals say
items.description: Torres Strait Island leaders say federal government claims of strong border protections do not match what communities are seeing on their doorstep in Queensland's far north.

items.title: Trump has mostly held his plans for Venezuela close to his chest — until now
items.description: Until this week, the Trump administration had provided few details about how involved it would be in Venezuela's governance. New information suggests it will look to hold the purse strings for some time.

items.title: Which US forces have been sent to the Middle East, and what does their arrival mean?
items.description: A US aircraft carrier, supporting warships, fighter jets and air-defence systems have arrived in the Middle East, as the world waits to see to what action — if any — Donald Trump will take against Iran.
